channel.title: The Idea of a Secondary Cache
channel.description:
Well, I've been looking into the client figuring out all sorts of crazy things, like placing those damn map functions around (And the fact that it's semi-automated is... kinda shocking) and instead of making a tool to edit all the existing data, we can make our own cache that overrides existing stuff. This is pretty much hardcoding, but everything we do would be in one file (It wouldn't be a zip, or some other type of known archive, but it would be my own).
I'm honestly sick the current way of hardcoding stuff and the fact that we can't edit everything (Well... I'm not sure how far Tom's Cache Suite goes but I don't think it loads on-demand data) with ease. If we used the secondary cache, even if it meant using the same format for things such as maps, we would still be able to edit everything as long as it was programmed in.
Now, if we only allowed the overriding of existing content, we wouldn't be able to edit things already in-game. But, that's where either using a cache extractor comes in hand, or dumping the data as it's loaded during the client's run time. I'm not sure how far the dumping tools out there go, but if they don't do everything we need, I'd gladly dump things such as maps, or the "landscape file" (so I've heard).
So I'd love to work on something like this, which includes tools, but it depends on how much it'd be used. What do you guys think? Give me your opinions.
~Lin

item.title: The Idea of a Secondary Cache
item.dc:creator: @CreatorAlex CreatorAlex
item.description:
@CreatorAlex wrote:

I like the idea.

Sounds like it would expand what we can do with clients a good bit.

Read full topic
item.source: The Idea of a Secondary Cache

item.title: The Idea of a Secondary Cache
item.dc:creator: @CoonHunter CoonHunter
item.description:
@CoonHunter wrote:

The main piece here that would be nice, is being able to pack multiple things into the same data file. Instead of a separate data and index file for models, animations, interfaces etc.

Read full topic

item.description:

It would be a cool little thing to have, you should build upon the idea.

item.title: The Idea of a Secondary Cache
item.dc:creator: @odoat odoat
item.description:
@odoat wrote:

Go for it. I don’t want to say it would “revolutionize” RSPS clients, but it’s certainly a step in the right direction!

Good luck, I’d be willing to design a project site or something if it would help at all… (Probably wouldn’t, but whatevs haha).

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @Lin Lin
item.description:
@Lin wrote:

Oh, very odd. It didn’t seem to be like that for interface drawing, nor when loading images. When I extracted and displayed images, there were 24BPP and drawing them worked fine.

item.dc:creator: @peterbjornx peterbjornx

lin there is a 256 colour restriction but not in the way of 8 bit RGB but in the way of a 256 entry’s big palette with 24bit colours

item.source: The Idea of a Secondary Cache

item.title: The Idea of a Secondary Cache
item.dc:creator: @Lin Lin
item.description:
@Lin wrote:

[quote=“Stale Milk, post:1, topic:350767”]Ever heard of a hardcode packer?

The only ‘secondary cache’ that should be required is an image cache to prevent 256 color restriction on images. Palidino76 released his ages ago…[/quote]Yes, and images in the cache are not restricted to 256 colors. There are 3 bytes per pixel, and the data is directly copied when displayed.

Read full topic
item.source: The Idea of a Secondary Cache

item.title: The Idea of a Secondary Cache
item.dc:creator: @roguex roguex
item.description:
@roguex wrote:

I have seen something very much like what you are talking about. For example packing all the custom models, animations into your own cache. Its actually not that hard to do, you may want to add a basic encryption to the cache, to stop leeching.

You can send the custom cache using the update protocol, either using the jaggrab system and request the custom cache from that or via http.

Read full topic
item.source: The Idea of a Secondary Cache

That would be something to have a secondary cache.

item.title: The Idea of a Secondary Cache
item.dc:creator: @Thing1 Thing1
item.description:
@Thing1 wrote:

Pack it all to the original Jagex cache, that’s the most proper way…
Ive packed all 474 gfx, npcs, animations, objects, textures, models, and sounds into a 317 cache.
With some work you guys should be able to too.

Read full topic

item.title: The Idea of a Secondary Cache
item.dc:creator: @Lin Lin
item.description:
@Lin wrote:

Somewhat. I’m not going to bother explaining it since I explained it in the topic post…

Obviously it can be added for any revision, or even different games altogether. All the secondary cache will be a big file with other files inside of it. All that would have to be done to the client is make it unpack the files and do stuff with them.
